p: Morus alba L. belongs to the Moraceae family. It is a deciduous shrub or tree that is grown naturally, and is widely cultivated for medicinal and edible purposes. Four M. alba parts have been used medicinally, as registered in the Korean pharmacopeias, including the twigs (Sang-Ji, Mori Ramulus), leaves (Sang-Yeop, Mori Folium), fruits (Sang-Sim-Ja, Mori Fructus), and root barks (Sanb-Baek-Pi, Mori Radicis Cortex), each of which have different therapeutic efficacies [ 1, 2]. Each medicinal M. alba part has various pharmacological effects due to its specific phytochemicals. For example, twigs have hepatoprotective effects from stilbenes [ 3], root barks have phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitory effects from flavonoids [ 4], fruits have anti-diabetic activities from phenolic compounds and flavonoids [ 5], and leaves have anti-cancer effects from phenolic compounds [ 6]. Furthermore, each medicinal part presents different chemical compositions, and shows distinguishable pharmacological effects, such as the differences in the anti-oxidant, anti-microbial, anti-diabetic, anti-inflammatory, and anti-tyrosinase effects of the leaves, fruits, twigs, stems, and root barks [ 7, 8, 9].
